Early in the seventh century, wandering Sassanian monks supposed haggis to be a cross between a fish and a mammal (which indeed they once were) but over time haggis developed a taste for heather and consequently lost their gills and the ability to breathe underwater.
To back up this theory, it is said by the esteemed and knowledgeable Dinnet and Ballater scientific and archaeology fraternity (especially after a wee dram or twa), that the first mammals on Earth were in fact, offshoots of ancient haggis, ergo the transitional missing link between fish and mammal.
The key supporting evidence is a group of reddish-coloured rocks on the eastern side of 'The Minch' known as the Stac Fada deposit, dated over a billion years old, lying between the Western Isles and mainland Scotland, where fossilised remains of ancient haggis-like creatures were first discovered.
Coincidentally, a few years ago, archaeologists discovered that some Scottish crannogs (fortified settlements constructed on artificial islands in lochs) were thousands of years older than previously thought. It was thought they were first built in the Iron Age, a period that began around 800 BC. Four of these sites have been radiocarbon dated to about 3640-3360 BC in the Neolithic period - before the erection of Stonehenge's stone circle. It is on these crannogs, however, that there is a vast perfusion of ancient, fossilised haggis bones, suggesting that long ago they were bred by early man for their meat or even guard haggis to warn off predators.
